is of a handsome young flight candidate in uniform, with stylish little moustache and dark bedroom eyes.

Your real father was an Officer  candidate like me?

I know that.
With a smile that almost quells her concern, he drives of Paula watches him until he disappears.
SHOOTING THROUGH the passenger window, PAST Sid and Lynet making out hot and heavy, TO Zack as he drives up on his  motorcycle.

I don't believe that. They're just  having a good time, same as us.

Zack, Sid, Casey, Perryman and Della-Serra are struggling erect a shelter in the driving downpour, using a parachut and logs they've cut. It's a hokey little tepee at best b they crowd inside it as THUNDER and lightning herald a bl of monsoon-like rainfall. The shelter collapses on top of them.

In the hinterlands beyond the Navy base is an Air Force b with vast acreage of swamplands and tundra. Okay, worms. This is it. Can you  pussies live through three days  without food or water in the  wilderness? This is where we thin  our ranks the "natural" way, children.  Incidentally, those little twigs you  see floating in those mud puddles  aren't twigs. They're water moccasins.
reveal that he's right. Lethal-looking snakes slither and glide over the surface of the swamp waters.
reflect what you'd expect. Fear. Even Zack looks wary of ordeal ahead.

captures the humor of the next three days of survival  training. Paula is on the line, sorting colors, while Lynette talks a payphone on the other side of the cavernous room. The n of the processors and conveyors is terrible, but her cowo Bunny, 38, a faded, jaded deb if there ever was one, call to her above the din:
You and Lynette still seeing those  flight candidates over to Pensacola?

Comes a time right after they get  through survival training when they  start to think they can make it  without you. Suddenly they stop  calling. Suddenly they own the goddamn  world. (beat) He hasn't called you by now, Paula,  he ain't gonna call.

May they all crash and burn.
He's at the barracks pay phone.
Sid Worley, I think you're ashamed  of me.

STARTING ON Zack, eating at Mach Five. THEN INCLUDE Sid a his parents, TOM and BETTY WORLEY, two of the world's  straightest human beings, stiffly WASPish in spite of the down-home Oklahoma drawls, people with so much moral fibe it shines humorless through everything they say or do.

CAMERA MOVES with Sid and Zack as they make their way tow the LOUD ROCK MUSIC coming out of the legendary "TRADER
Thanks for covering for me.

My girl back home. We're supposed to  get married after I get my wings.  She was Tommy's girl. They were  engaged to be married before he died. (beat) I should've told you about her. I  don't know why I didn't, except I  didn't want you to think I was a  shit for making it with Lynette.

(distracted) Listen, I'm not going to go to that  little reunion party. I'm meeting  Lynette at the motel. (a sheepish grin) Best head in fifty-two states. After  three days of survival training, how  could I resist?
Zack rubs his buddy's bristle-brush of hair, affectionate

Lynette told me it really tore her  up when you didn't call this week.

There's women for you, pard. They  tell you they're in it for the laughs,  but it's always a fucking lie. (a loud whoop) Look out, Trader Jon's, I'm in the  mood for some fun!

STARTING ON THE PHOTOS of The Blue Angels that crowd the  walls... a lithe, young stripper DANCES INTO FRAME. Hangi from a net overhead are countless model airplanes. Seeger, Della-Serra, Perryman and Zack are at the bar, dr raised in toast.

They clink glasses. As the others sip their beers, Zack d a double shot of tequila and pushes his glass toward the  grizzly-looking bartender, old TRADER JON himself.
Give me another double Tequila.

His shipmates share a look. Seeger's attention then shift to the dancer. What a body she has. Perfect little coffee cup breasts. A bottom that tightens and relaxes like a fi as she dances to the loud, rock music.
(watching the dancer) Not bad.

Cool it, Emiliano. I don't find it  funny.
CAMERA MOVES with the dancer, away from the group and we:
Zack is hoisting a chair with shells onto the bar top.
(smashed) Lemme show you little game called  "Crash and Burn".
He climbs up on the bar and sits down in the chair. The  Olongapo Kid.
Listen up, dick-brains! This is how  we separate the jet jockeys from the  helo-boys. Guy who flies the farthest  without crashing and burning... he's  hot shit!
Seeger, Perryman and Della-Serra glance nervously around place. Nobody thinks it's that funny, especially Trader J
Come on, Mayo! You're gonna get our  asses in trouble, man!
Get down from there, before they  call the shore patrol.
Come on! Give me a push! Never hochi  in the P.I. you see jet-jockey so  hot like me!
Hey, buddy, cool it.
Seeger approaches Zack.
Zack, we've got to go.
Just trying to have fun. That fucking  prison is really starting to get to  me. C'mon, Seeger. Gimme a push. (beat) Fuck you guys! I'll do it myself!

He pushes off with his feet and the chair glides down the bar, knocking over glasses and beer bottles. The chair an its rider topple over the bar and Zack goes sprawling ont table, laughing like a looney.
Okay, that's it!
Seeger quickly turns to her cohorts.
You guys take care of Trader Jon  while I get him out of here.
Perryman and Della-Serra nod and head off to deal with th man while she goes to Zack.
C'mon, Zack. We've got to get out of  here!
He allows her to lead him toward the exit.
Casey pushes him into the backseat of a taxi, but Zack gr her by the hand and tries to pull her inside.
C'mon, Seeger. Let's go to the Tides  Inn Motel.
He pulls her close and kisses her on the lips, but she ge pulls away.
You're cute, Mayo, but you don't  want me. And to tell you the truth,  I don't want you. (a quick kiss) See you back at the base.
She gives the driver a fiver and the taxi drives off.

location: SID AND LYNETTE'S ROOM AT THE TIDES INN

text: Sid lies in bed, staring up at the ceiling. WIDEN to incl Lynette, just starting to get dressed beside the bed.
By the way, shouldn't you have had a  period by now?
I'm a little late, that's all.
How late?
What difference does it make? If  anything was to happen, which I'm  sure it isn't, it would be my  responsibility.
Exactly how late are you, Lynette?
(playing him) What do you care? Suppose I was  pregnant. Just suppose it. You don't  think I'd try to make you do anything  you don't want to, do you?
No. But that's not the only issue  here, sweetheart. There's a lot more  to it than that.
She's like an expert fisherman, working her catch, easing in so deftly it never feels the hook.
What other issue is there, Sid?
My responsibility as its father, for  one. I mean, if I've made you  pregnant, I'd want to... do the right  thing.
Lynette waits hopefully.
...I'd want to pay for the abortion...  I'd want to be with you through the  whole thing... by your side. (beat) So how late are you, Lynette?
(cold) Let's just wait and see what happens.
She finishes dressing and leaves.
Zack sits in the shower, the water blasting down on his h Sid bursts in.
Zack? God, I'm glad I found you. I  need to talk to you, buddy.
Zack is a zombie. He groans and gestures Sid off.
Talk to me in the morning. I feel  like shit.
But it can't wait.
He presses close to the shower, so preoccupied he doesn't even notice the water spattering his uniform.
Guess fucking what! Lynette's missed  her period. What am I gonna do, Zack?  What can I tell my folks?
What on God's green earth do I say to Susan.
Calm down, Sweet Pea. She seen a  doctor?
No, but she's gotta be at least a  month late.
Doesn't mean shit. Get her to a  doctor. You can't do anything until  you hear what he says. Make the  appointment yourself.

The class is taking a critical multiple choice exam. Zack struggles against his basic instinct to cheat off of Case paper. He's still slower than most of the others but he's doing okay. It's Sid who's slipping under. His mind is so far away he hasn't even bothered to write his name at the top of the exam paper.
The class, down to a scrappy 23 survivors, comes running after the exam, Foley right on their heels.
Fall out on the lawn in five minutes!  This is your last shot at the 101  Course... Mayo... Seeger... Della- Serra...
As the rest of the class goes bounding up the stairwell. rushes up to the O.O.D.
Sir, request permission to make an  emergency phone call, sir!
The O.O.D. nods and Sid starts feeding quarter into the  payphone on the wall. Zack hangs back, concerned.
Move it, Mayo!
Zack glares at Foley and runs up the stairs.
STARTING TIGHT on Seeger's face as Foley starts her.
Go!
He starts several of the others AD LIB. Then it's Zack's  turn.
Go!

Zack takes off across the course with a gleam in his eye. wants that record. Zack dances through the innertubes, ha over hands the parallel bars, and churns his way through stretch of knee-deep sand, his classmates cheering him on wanting the record, too, wanting to leave their mark. They all wear warmups similar to the ones worn by the cra squad they saw in the early days of training, except that their shirts are gold and their pants are blue. On the front of their shirts is an insignia and the words "FOLEY'S FIRE EATERS." Their nicknames have been printed  boldly on the back: "MAYONNAISE," "B. SANDWICH," "THE MAR

WORRY?," ETC. Across the back of Foley's all red warmup s are these words: "YOU'RE PISSING ME OFF, BOY!" As Zack passes his slower classmates, they add their shou of encouragement to the cheering from the sidelines. "Do Mayo!" "Put our name up there, Mayonnaise!" "You can do i Zack shimmies up a rope, yanks his body over the low hurd crawls on his back under the low horizontal bars, scamper up the angled beam, leaps the moat... and is approaching wall full tilt when he sees Seeger up ahead, struggling a usual to get over it.
(calling) Come on, Seeger! Let's go over it  together!

He makes it in one leap but she falls back to the ground, beaten. Zack pauses at the top of the wall and looks down her. Foley watches from the distance. Zack drops back down beside Seeger. She has tears of  frustration in her eyes. She's not going to make it and the realization that she's come this far only to fail is crushing her.
Go on, Zack! Go for the record!

Fuck the record. Now you listen to  me and do exactly what I tell you. (he draws a line with  his foot) Start back ten yards and take off  from here. Not here... or there...  but right here! (the total officer) No excuses, Seeger! You are going to  plant those legs here and then you're  going to yank yourself over that  wall because you have to! You want  jets? Then do it, goddamnit!

Seeger nods, almost mesmerized by his decisive tone of vo his sudden emergence as a leader. She starts running, tak off exactly on the mark, and struggles to the top of the  wall. She drops down on the other side and Zack joins her, smil
and shakes his head. He can live without that record.
As they finish the course, they stop and hug each other.  Then something catches Zack's eye that chases the good  feelings away.

Big Sid is trudging slowly toward the 101 Course in his  warmup, his nickname: "LOVERBOY" somehow ironic, especial in this moment. Sid sees Zack looking his way and signals the news to him by putting his arms into a baby-cradling  position and rocking the imaginary off-spring from side t side.
Zack and Sid are in line, getting their food.
It's a big religious thing with her  and she won't even discuss it.
But she expects you to marry her?
She said it was up to me. If I don't,  she'll go off and have the baby on  her own somewhere.
At the mention of the word "baby" nearby classmates perk  their ears up.
So what's the problem? Girls do that  all the time.
I can't let her go off and have the  kid by herself and not do anything.  If it's my kid, too, then I've got a  responsibility, don't I?
Not if she won't even talk about an  abortion.
But it would still be my kid. That's  the point.
Do you know that for sure?
It's mine.
They leave the food line and start toward the tables.
Okay, but what if it's like Foley  said and she got knocked up, to trap  you -- is it still your  responsibility?

No matter how it happened, if she  goes ahead and has it" Zack, there'll  be a child in the world that's mine -- and I couldn't go through life knowing  that and not knowing its name or  where it lived.
Jesus Christ, Sid! Is everything  your responsibility?
Sid and Zack sit down with their classmates and start eat

Your brother getting killed instead  of you... Isn't that why you promised  to marry this Susan? Isn't that why  you do everything, man? Out of some  bullshit code of ethics you inherited  from your family?
Foley can be seen at the Instructors' table, IN SHOT BACKGROUND, watching them, but Sid and Zack are oblivious their audience.

(angrily) Maybe it's all bullshit to you, but  that's now how I was raised. I believe  we have a responsibility to the people  in our lives -- that that's the only  thing that separates us from the  goddamn animals! (beat) I'm not like you, Mayo. I can't just  shit on people and then sleep like a  baby all night!
The words sting and Zack flares back at his friend.
You got a responsibility to you first,  pard -- and if you can't handle that,  you've got bigger problems than  getting a girl pregnant!
They stare at each other a long time, but no more words c

Wearing full oxygen masks, Zack and Sid are part of a gro of six candidates playing pat-a-cake at simulated altitud inside the claustrophobic-small decompression chamber. An INSTRUCTOR is explaining the test over an intercom, from  outside the windowed chamber.
Now everybody take off your masks  but continue the same exercise. The  purpose is to show you the effects  of altitude on the motor skills when  you've been cut off from your oxygen.
Slowly their reactions begin to deteriorate. At first Sid seems amused by his and Zack's fumbling to slap hands. Th as a SHINING SOUND mounts into a crazy place, he begins t panic.
(suddenly, calling) Stop this thing! I said stop it!

Everyone looks at him strangely. Sid lurches like a drunk his feet and tries to move toward the door. He trips over himself and falls, then stays there with his hands on his ears and his body curled into a fetal position.
I want out! Let me out! Please! Let  me out!
Zack extricates himself from his harness like a man with  eight thumbs condemned on top of it to move in slow motio He weaves, drops to his knees by Sid, and awkwardly tries enclose him in his arms.
Sid, it's okay. Don't be afraid.
The WHINING STOPS as they start to back off on the pressu inside the chamber, but they can't do it too fast. Slowly Sid comes to his senses, and his eyes focus on Zack.
Sid, what happened?
I don't know... I felt like... like  I was suffocating... Christ, Zack...  I was so scared... so godddamn  scared...
Tears are running down Sid's face.
Hey, man, don't cry... not in front  of the instructors.

Zack looks around at the faces, all staring back in judge not just the instructors. By now, the candidates know the symptoms of a DOR as well as anybody. The door to the chamber slams open and Foley is standing  there, grim-faced.

Zack is on morning "colors" duty. He and one of the lesse known candidates are raising the flag, a bugler standing  nearby, blowing "morning colors". Zack suddenly sees some that chills him. Sid and Foley stand in front of the Admin. Building, Fole saluting the flag, Sid just standing there arms at his si shoulders slumped. As the bugler finishes, Zack turns to his classmate.
I gotta do something.
He breaks into a run.
as he runs toward Foley and Sid and walks with them towar the water.
(to Foley) You didn't kick him out...? Wait,  didn't he tell you what he's been  going through?
It doesn't matter what he's going  through. That's the whole purpose of  this zoo. What matters is he freaked  out for some reason at twenty-five  thousand feet and that can't ever  happen again.
But you don't understand. There's  this girl he's gotten pregnant and  she's putting him through hell, sir.
He's right, Zack. It doesn't matter.
Just like that it's all over? With  less than two weeks to go, you're  out?
It can still happen to you, too,  Mayo.
Foley marches off like a windup toy.
(furious) Come back here, motherfucker!
Foley spins around, his eyes sparkling wildly.
What did you call me, Mayo?
Zack, don't!
I thought the D.I.'s were supposed  to help you in this place! What kind  of human being are you?
Stop eyeballing me, Mayo, or you're  out!
Please, Zack -- go back to the  barracks!
I don't get it! He's the best  candidate in our class! Ask anyone!  The best student! The best leader!  The best friend to everybody! Couldn't  you bend your goddamn standards just  a little?
Zack, it wasn't him! He didn't ask  me to D.O.R. I came to him on my  own. (beat) I'm glad it's over, Zack. I really  mean that. He was right. I wasn't  doing this for me.
He feels his tears coming up so he runs off suddenly acro the parade ground.
Sid, wait! Where're you going?
Sid keeps running. Zack turns back to Foley and they star at each other a long moment before Zack bitterly salutes  him.
With your permission, sir.
Foley returns the salute and watches Zack walk off toward the barracks.
Zack drives up on his motorcycle. Esther is in the yard,  gardening.
Is Paula here?
Paula suddenly appears on the porch, dressed in a simple  cotton dress, her hair un-coiffed, none of her Deb makeup
I'm looking for Sid.
So?
Paula, he DORed and nobody's seen  him.
Why'd he do it?
Hey! You know goddamn well what  happened so let's not play any games,  okay?
I'm not playing any games! Go look  at Lynette's!
I don't know where that is.
Paula slowly moves to him and gets on the motorcycle behi him. They speed off, Esther watching them go.

She sits on the porch of the old home she was born in, he hair up in curlers, doing her nails. The National Paper m sends up pillars of smoke on the horizon. A taxi drives u and Sid steps out, in a sport coat and tie.
Hi, babe. Come on. I've got a couple  of things I want to tell you.
What're you doing out of uniform,  Sid? You don't want to get in trouble.
Forget that. Come on. Got a little  surprise...
I can't go like this. Can't you wait  a few minutes 'til I'm ready?
No way. I'm so happy I'm about to  bust. Here, honey. This is for you.  It cost me my whole savings, but I  said what the fuck.
He hands her a little box. She opens it and finds an  engagement ring. She looks up at him, happily.
Sid! Oh, it's beautiful! You mean...
That's right. Let's get married,  Lynette. Let's find a justice of the  peace and just do it!
Lynette tries the ring on.
(euphoric) Let's go tell Paula! God, I wonder  where we'll be stationed first. I  hope it'll be Hawaii. I've always  wanted to go to Hawaii.
We're not gonna be stationed anywhere,  baby. I DORed.
(shaken) You what?
I had to, baby... I'm no aviator. I  was faking it, like I was with  everything else in my life... up  'til right now.
But... but what would we do? Where  would we go?

Oklahoma. I can get my old job back  at JC Penney's. In a couple of years,  I'll be floor manager. Oh, you're  gonna love Oklahoma, Lynette. You  and mama'll get along just great. Of  course, money will be a little tight  for a while, but we'll make it.
(suddenly) Sid, there's no baby.
What?
I'm not pregnant. I got my period  this morning. There's no baby, Sid.
Well, I'll be goddamned.
Sid stares at her disbelievingly, but she's telling the t at least partly. There is no baby.

(a big smile) What do you say we get married anyway?  I love you, Lynette. I'm in love  with you... and I didn't realize it  until right this second... but I've  never been happier in my life than I  have been the last seven weekends,  never more relaxed... more loved for  just who I am... (beat) Marry me, Lynette. I love you.
Lynette looks off at the factory, then back at Sid.

I'm sorry, Sid, but I don't want to  marry you. I like you a lot and we  had ourselves some real nice times,  that's for sure... but I thought you  understood. I want to marry a pilot,  Sid. I want to live part of my life  overseas... the wife of an aviator,  Sid. (bitterly) Damn you! Goddamn you! Nobody DORs  after eleven weeks! Nobody!
She throws the engagement ring at him and runs toward the house. Numb to his core, Sid slowly retrieves the ring an gets into her car. He starts it and drives off.
Hey! Come back with my car!
Lynette's Falcon takes a sudden turn. A split-second late Zack and Paula speed past in the opposite direction, miss him.
Zack and Paula drive up and move toward the front door.
Lynette??
They find her in the kitchen, sitting at the table, smoki a cigarette.
Lynette, where's Sid?
Already come and gone. Can you believe  it? He DORed in the twelfth week.  How can you win?
Zack grabs her by the shoulders and forces her to meet hi eyes.
What did you tell him about the baby?
That there isn't one, as of today. I  had my period. (beat) I couldn't believe it. He still wanted  to marry me.
And you turned him down??
Of course. I don't want no Okie from  Muscogee. I can get that right here  in Port Angeles.
Zack starts shaking her angrily.
You little bitch! How could you? Was  there ever a baby, Lynette? That's  all I want to know! Did you make up  that baby, Lynette? Did you??
(caught) Of course there was a baby. I'd never  lie about something like that. Would  I, Paula?
She looks at Paula for support but she seems to be wonder the same things herself, and offers none. Zack abruptly p out of the room, leaving the two girls alone.
Lynette, did you make up that baby  or didn't you?
Lynette's silence is answer enough. Paula suddenly slaps across the face with all her might.
God help you, Lynette!
You're no better than me, Paula!  You're just the same!
No! That's not true!
She runs from the room.
Zack is getting on his motorcycle as she emerges from the house.
I'd like to come with you.
Why?
Because he's my friend, too.
She gets on and he doesn't try to stop her. PAN as they d off.

Carrying a pint bottle of bourbon, Sid weaves his way int the office. He smiles a quirky smile for the WOMAN behind the counter as he hands her some money and she gives him key. As he turns away from the counter, the woman calls after  him.
Hey, is this yours?
She holds up the engagement ring he bought for Lynette. S smiles, takes it from her.
Ever seen this one?
He pops the ring in his mouth and swallows it as the woma looks on, speechless. Sid weaves out.
